title: Bound in std::ops - Rust
markdown:
# Bound in std::ops - Rust

## Enum [std](../index.html)::[ops](index.html)::[Bound](#)

1.17.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/range.rs.html#672) Â·

```
pub enum Bound<T> {
    Included(T),
    Excluded(T),
    Unbounded,
}
```

Expand description

An endpoint of a range of keys.

## [Â§](#examples)Examples

`Bound`s are range endpoints:

```
use std::ops::Bound::*;
use std::ops::RangeBounds;

assert_eq!((..100).start_bound(), Unbounded);
assert_eq!((1..12).start_bound(), Included(&1));
assert_eq!((1..12).end_bound(), Excluded(&12));
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::ops::Bound::*;%0A++++use+std::ops::RangeBounds;%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!((..100).start_bound(),+Unbounded);%0A++++assert_eq!((1..12).start_bound(),+Included(%261));%0A++++assert_eq!((1..12).end_bound(),+Excluded(%2612));%0A%7D&edition=2021)

Using a tuple of `Bound`s as an argument to [`BTreeMap::range`](about:blank/std/collections/btree_map/struct.BTreeMap.html#method.range). Note that in most cases, itâ€™s better to use range syntax (`1..5`) instead.

```
use std::collections::BTreeMap;
use std::ops::Bound::{Excluded, Included, Unbounded};

let mut map = BTreeMap::new();
map.insert(3, "a");
map.insert(5, "b");
map.insert(8, "c");

for (key, value) in map.range((Excluded(3), Included(8))) {
    println!("{key}: {value}");
}

assert_eq!(Some((&3, &"a")), map.range((Unbounded, Included(5))).next());
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::collections::BTreeMap;%0A++++use+std::ops::Bound::%7BExcluded,+Included,+Unbounded%7D;%0A++++%0A++++let+mut+map+=+BTreeMap::new();%0A++++map.insert(3,+%22a%22);%0A++++map.insert(5,+%22b%22);%0A++++map.insert(8,+%22c%22);%0A++++%0A++++for+(key,+value)+in+map.range((Excluded(3),+Included(8)))+%7B%0A++++++++println!(%22%7Bkey%7D:+%7Bvalue%7D%22);%0A++++%7D%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(Some((%263,+%26%22a%22)),+map.range((Unbounded,+Included(5))).next());%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[Â§](#variant.Included)1.17.0

An inclusive bound.

[Â§](#variant.Excluded)1.17.0

An exclusive bound.

[Â§](#variant.Unbounded)1.17.0

An infinite endpoint. Indicates that there is no bound in this direction.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/range.rs.html#684)[Â§](#impl-Bound%3CT%3E)

1.65.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/range.rs.html#688)

Converts from `&Bound<T>` to `Bound<&T>`.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/range.rs.html#699)

ðŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`bound_as_ref`Â [#80996](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/80996))

Converts from `&mut Bound<T>` to `Bound<&mut T>`.

1.77.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/range.rs.html#730)

Maps a `Bound<T>` to a `Bound<U>` by applying a function to the contained value (including both `Included` and `Excluded`), returning a `Bound` of the same kind.

##### [Â§](#examples-1)Examples

```
use std::ops::Bound::*;

let bound_string = Included("Hello, World!");

assert_eq!(bound_string.map(|s| s.len()), Included(13));
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::ops::Bound::*;%0A++++%0A++++let+bound_string+=+Included(%22Hello,+World!%22);%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(bound_string.map(%7Cs%7C+s.len()),+Included(13));%0A%7D&edition=2021)

```
use std::ops::Bound;
use Bound::*;

let unbounded_string: Bound<String> = Unbounded;

assert_eq!(unbounded_string.map(|s| s.len()), Unbounded);
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::ops::Bound;%0A++++use+Bound::*;%0A++++%0A++++let+unbounded_string:+Bound%3CString%3E+=+Unbounded;%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(unbounded_string.map(%7Cs%7C+s.len()),+Unbounded);%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/range.rs.html#739)[Â§](#impl-Bound%3C%26T%3E)

1.55.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/ops/range.rs.html#753)

Map a `Bound<&T>` to a `Bound<T>` by cloning the contents of the bound.

##### [Â§](#examples-2)Examples

```
use std::ops::Bound::*;
use std::ops::RangeBounds;

assert_eq!((1..12).start_bound(), Included(&1));
assert_eq!((1..12).start_bound().cloned(), Included(1));
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++use+std::ops::Bound::*;%0A++++use+std::ops::RangeBounds;%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!((1..12).start_bound(),+Included(%261));%0A++++assert_eq!((1..12).start_bound().cloned(),+Included(1));%0A%7D&edition=2021)
